question.title: How come I am seeing different files in my JavaVirtualMachines folder depending on how I navigate to the folder in Terminal?
question.body:
I am using Terminal on my MacBook.

From the top directory if I do:

cd Library
cd Java
cd JavaVirtualMachines
ls

I see the following files:

corretto-21.0.5 corretto-22.0.2 openjdk-20.0.2  openjdk-23.0.1  openjdk-23.0.2

But if in the top directory I instead do:

cd /Library/Java/JavaVirtualMachines
ls

I see the following files:

jdk-21.jdk      jdk-24.jdk      jdk1.8.0_202.jdk

answers.body:
From the top directory if I do

The top directory of a folder, but certainly not your very top directory. You do

cd Library
cd Java
cd JavaVirtualMachines
ls

So if your top directory was

/my/custom/path/here

then you reach

/my/custom/path/here/Library/Java/JavaVirtualMachines

whereas when you do:

cd /Library/Java/JavaVirtualMachines

then you specify absolute path, not relative to your current folder.

question_comments.body: macOS has two Library folders, one in your home directory (but hidden by Finder), and one in the root directory.

By the way, a tip: Installing and using SDKMAN! is the easiest way to locate, download, install, and uninstall a Java JDK/JRE on macOS. You will find all its JDKs in ~/.sdkman/candidates/ though you'll never need look there in either the Terminal nor the Finder. Just use SDKMAN! on the console (in Terminal.app) to see what JDKs you have installed.

The command pwd (print working directory) - if available - should show the differences: That you're in different folders. Navigation is always relative to the current folder, unless the first char is /. Then it's absolute addressing.
